peripatus.name: Peripatus
peripatus.description: A primitive, caterpillar-like terrestrial invertebrate known as a "living fossil."
introduction: It is a nocturnal, carnivorous animal found in damp places like crevices of rocks, bark, and leaf litter. It is famously known as a connecting link between Annelida and Arthropoda, exhibiting characters of both phyla.
features: Level of Organisation: Organ-system level of organisation
Body plan: Tube within a tube body plan (Protostomous)
Respiratory type: Tracheal system (Tracheae open through diffused spiracles)
Circulation system: Open (Haemolymph flows in sinuses)
Regulation of Osmosis: Osmoregulator (Weak, restricted to moist habitats)
sizeStructure: Size: Small body ranging from 2 cm to 15 cm in length.
Shape: Worm-like, cylindrical, and caterpillar-like body with unjointed legs (lobopods).
Colour: Dark grey, brown, or reddish, matching the soil or leaf litter.
Special external features: Skin has a velvety texture due to numerous minute papillae; head bears a pair of antennae and oral papillae.
ecology: Acts as a predator, feeding on small invertebrates like termites, beetles, and snails.
Serves as a prey for larger predators such as birds, lizards, and spiders.
Functions as an indicator of a healthy, moist forest ecosystem.
economy: Scientific Importance: Vital evolutionary evidence as a connecting link between Annelida and Arthropoda.
Research: Studied for its unique projectile slime mechanism (bio-adhesives).
Biodiversity: Represents an ancient lineage unchanged for millions of years (Living Fossil).

palaemon.name: Palaemon
palaemon.description: A common crustacean found in freshwater and marine environments, widely studied as a type specimen for Arthropoda.
introduction: It is a nocturnal, bottom-dwelling omnivore inhabiting freshwater rivers, ponds, and streams (some species are marine). It is economically significant as a food source and ecologically vital as a scavenger.
features: Level of Organisation: Organ-system level of organisation
Body plan: Tube within a tube body plan (Protostomous)
Circulation system: Open (Haemolymph flows in sinuses)
Regulation of Osmosis: Osmoregulator (Maintained by Green glands)
Nervous system: Ganglionated double ventral nerve cord
Development type: Indirect development (Larval stage: Zoea)
sizeStructure: Size: Varies by species, generally elongated, ranging from 2.5 cm to over 30 cm (e.g., P. malcolmsonii).
Shape: Spindle-shaped, bilaterally symmetrical body divided into cephalothorax and abdomen.
Colour: Usually pale blue or translucent white, turning orange-red when cooked.
Special external features: Body protected by a hard carapace with a serrated, saw-like rostrum extending forward; possesses 19 pairs of jointed appendages.
ecology: Acts as a scavenger and omnivore, feeding on algae, decaying matter, and small insects.
Serves as a primary food source for larger aquatic predators like fish and water birds.
Helps in cleaning the water body by consuming organic debris and detritus.
economy: Food Industry: A major source of protein, widely consumed globally as a delicacy.
Aquaculture: Extensively farmed in "Prawn Culture" industries due to high growth rates.
Economy: High commercial export value contributes significantly to the fisheries economy.

macrobrachium.name: Macrobrachium
macrobrachium.scientificName: Giant Freshwater Prawn / Scampi / River Prawn
macrobrachium.description: A genus of large freshwater crustaceans extensively farmed for food, commercially known as "Scampi."
introduction: It inhabits freshwater rivers, lakes, and canals, though larvae often require brackish water. It is nocturnal, bottom-dwelling, and highly aggressive, known for its massive growth potential in aquaculture.
features: Level of Organisation: Organ-system level of organisation
Body plan: Tube within a tube body plan (Protostomous)
Circulation system: Open (Haemolymph flows in sinuses)
Regulation of Osmosis: Osmoregulator (Active ion transport)
Skeleton structure: Exoskeleton (Hard, calcareous, and chitinous)
Nervous system: Ganglionated double ventral nerve cord
Development type: Indirect development (Larval stage: Zoea)
Body temperature: Poikilothermic (Euryhaline during larval stages)
sizeStructure: Size: Large-bodied, reaching 30 cm or more in species like M. rosenbergii.
Shape: Elongated, cylindrical body with a rigid cephalothorax and muscular abdomen.
Colour: Greenish-blue to brownish-grey; mature males often have deep blue claws.
Special external features: Characterized by extremely long, powerful second pair of walking legs (chelipeds) and a long, serrated rostrum.
ecology: Dominant benthic predator and scavenger in freshwater ecosystems.
Controls populations of snails and aquatic insects.
Serves as a key food source for predatory fish, wetland birds, and otters.
economy: Aquaculture: The primary species for freshwater prawn farming (Blue Revolution).
Food Industry: High-value export product marketed globally as Scampi.
Livelihood: Provides significant income for inland fish farmers in tropical regions.

cancer.name: Cancer
cancer.description:
Marine, benthic crustacean found in shallow seas.

features: Level of Organisation: Organ system level
Body plan: Tube within a tube body plan (Protostomous)
Nervous system: Paired ventral nerve cord
sizeStructure: Strong chelae and short abdomen folded ventrally
ecology: Acts as scavenger in marine ecosystem
